lexUnit.name: pack.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: to place in a container for transport or storage

sentence.text: Pack everything in a box , and keep it somewhere accessible -- ideally near the fusebox .
Behind them , housewives now pack .38s in Gucci handbags , learn to train Rottweilers in close attack work and sign up with security firms such as Armed Response .
He left John Fox , 25 , screaming in pain as his mum and horrified regulars packed his severed ear in ice .
They were glad to see it , as they had packed some food in one of the suitcases , and directly the porter had gone they set about preparing a meal .
She packed her mail in the saddlebag .
He would then pack them in wooden barrels , till he had a truck load , and then would send them direct from Plowden Station to the dye works where they were used .
Lowden have managed to pack a big sound into a small package and the end result is a guitar that can cope with anything from basic stage accompaniment to virtuoso-standard fingerpicking .
Her mother , Valerie Cass , was busying herself , packing things into a small overnight case .
At most colleges GCSE candidates pack two subjects into a week ; A level students take one at a time .
The robbers opened the strongroom and packed the cash into bags .
They packed five players into midfield to snuff out any Celtic creative instincts , and assistant manager Gerry Collins was delighted with the ploy .
If it was a warm , sunny day we would pack all our belongings into the caravan and then we would head to the beach or we would go swimming in the pool on the park .
He began to pack things into the picnic basket .
Mum paid for her shopping and gave Stuart the long receipt and they finished packing their bags into the trolley again while the supervisor took the cash from their till .
Henry started to pack the plates into the washing-up machine .
She began gathering plates and cutlery , then packed them into their hampers while the two guides dismantled the barbecue .
The following companies are featured in a short season that packs sixteen events into three days .
Although laser discs are used today mainly for music , you could pack the whole Encyclopaedia Britannica onto one of them , and read it out using the same laser technique .
Fairfax 's steward has packed sandwiches for us and an ancient vacuum flask of tea .
Nearly all the red-tiled-roof homes along the ridge line , high above Sarajevo , were deserted , with the last remaining people hurriedly packing their belongings on to cars and wagons .
Apart from the weapons , he had packed two sweat-shirts , some underwear and his toiletries .
Go and pack a few things , enough for a couple of days .
It is made from the liver , lungs and heart of a sheep with the addition of oatmeal and spices , all of which is packed into the sheep 's stomach .
She left the stove , grabbed her holdall and began packing everything back into it .
She had finished and packed her things when Lucy Grindal came in with a young woman .
Go and pack your things right now . "
I 'm goin' down the market now , then I 'll go 'ome and pack a few weekend things , then I 'll be back 'ere till Tuesday mornin' as it 's Bank Holiday .
Trimming costs even further is easy if you 're willing to pack yourselves in like sardines as the French normally do .
Parin nodded , and he signed to his assistants to roll up the books so that they could be packed away in the boxes and chests in which they were stored .

As the sheriff officers supervised the house clearance , construction officials measured the family pigeon lofts and dog runs for removal and the ferrets were packed away under the eyes of an animal welfare officer .
